quickScenarioChallenge.challengeSubtitle: Don't worry if you get it wrong‚Äîthat's how you learn!
quickScenarioChallenge.scenarioStory: You're managing a software project. Three issues have emerged: (1) A supplier is consistently late with component deliveries‚Äîit's a PATTERN, not a one-time delay. (2) Two team members are in constant conflict over technical decisions and their tension is slowing work. (3) A bug in the testing phase will require 2 weeks to fix (not originally planned). All three HAVE ALREADY HAPPENED (they're not 'potential risks'‚Äîthey're current issues). You need to address them.
quickScenarioChallenge.question: What's your primary approach to managing these issues?

options.A: Solve each issue yourself and tell the team the decisions
options.B: Recognize these as materialized risks that are now issues; collaborate with relevant stakeholders to determine the BEST solution for each
options.D: Escalate all of them to the sponsor immediately

ahaDebrief.correctAnswer: B - Recognize issues, collaborate with stakeholders to solve them

insights.explanation: Risk = 'Supplier MIGHT be late' (potential). Issue = 'Supplier IS late' (actual problem happening now). Issues require immediate action to resolve.
insights.pmbokSupport: Recognize when a risk has materialized into an issue and address it appropriately

insights.explanation: Supplier lateness? Talk to supplier + procurement team. Team conflict? Facilitate discussion between conflicted members. Testing bug? Include testers in solution. Collaborative solutions are better.
insights.pmbokSupport: Collaborate with relevant stakeholders to determine the optimal approach to resolve each issue

insights.explanation: You could tell the team to 'find a new supplier' (fast, PM-decided). Better: Work WITH supplier and procurement to understand root cause and improve. Better solution, more buy-in.
insights.pmbokSupport: Determine the optimal action to achieve project success, not just the quickest action

trapSection.explanation: Mishandling issues or solving them without stakeholder input.

trapTable.violation: You might solve them wrong (supplier issue = find new supplier, but they're 80% cheaper?). Team doesn't buy in.
Issues get WORSE. Late supplier becomes latER. Team conflict becomes project-threatening.

checklist: Is this a RISK (might happen) or an ISSUE (already happening)?
Did a risk materialize into an issue? (Yes = address as issue)
What's the negative impact? (Schedule, cost, quality?)
Who should be involved in solving this?
What's the optimal solution, not just the fastest?
patternRecognition.patternRule: Issues = materialized risks. Recognize them immediately. Collaborate with stakeholders to determine the BEST solution (not just your solution). Implement with team buy-in.

coreFramework.frameworkName: RESOLVE Framework for Managing Project Issues
coreFramework.frameworkIntro: Managing issues effectively requires recognition, analysis, and collaborative resolution:

rows.action: Identify when a RISK has become an ISSUE. 'Supplier might be late' ‚Üí Issue when they ARE late. 'Team conflict might slow work' ‚Üí Issue when it's slowing work NOW.
keyQuestions: Is this an issue or a risk?
Is this impacting the project RIGHT NOW?
rows.examKeywords: Recognize, materialized risk, issue identification, current problems

rows.action: Assess: How serious is this issue? Does it affect schedule? Cost? Quality? Morale? How urgent is resolution?
rows.examKeywords: Impact assessment, severity, urgency, constraints affected

rows.action: Identify who should be involved in solving this. Supplier issue? Include procurement. Team conflict? Include the conflicted team members. Get INPUT.
Generate multiple solutions. Supplier late ‚Üí (A) Escalate/penalize, (B) Work with them to improve, (C) Find new supplier, (D) Adjust schedule. What's BEST for the project?
keyQuestions: Which is best for project success?

rows.action: Once solution is chosen, execute it. Communicate clearly to all affected parties. Make sure everyone understands their role.
keyQuestions: Does everyone know what to do?

rows.action: Follow up. Is the supplier now on-time? Has team conflict resolved? Is the testing bug fixed? Confirm the issue is RESOLVED, not just addressed.

pmbokConnection.quote: Project managers recognize materialized risks as issues and collaborate with stakeholders to determine optimal solutions that ensure project success

visualReferenceCard.quickReference: **Issue management essentials:** Recognize materialized risks as issues | Assess impact urgently | Involve relevant stakeholders | Generate options collaboratively | Execute solution | Confirm resolution
visualReferenceCard.goldenRule: You don't solve issues alone. You recognize them, collaborate with stakeholders, determine the BEST solution (not your solution), and implement it together.
visualReferenceCard.examTip: Look for 'issue,' 'problem happening now,' or 'materialized risk' ‚Üí Recognize it as an issue ‚Üí Collaborate to find best solution ‚Üí Avoid making unilateral decisions.
visualReferenceCard.pmbokPrinciple: Recognize issues and collaborate with stakeholders to resolve them optimally

secondScenario.title: Apply RESOLVE Framework
secondScenario.scenarioStory: During project execution, you discover: (1) A key team member wants to leave (personal reasons, job offer elsewhere). (2) A critical system component is more expensive than budgeted‚Äî$200K over estimate. (3) Regulatory changes now require additional testing that wasn't originally planned. All three are NOW HAPPENING, not potential risks.
secondScenario.question: How should you address these issues?

options.A: Accept the team member's resignation, approve the $200K overrun, and hire consulting firm for extra testing (your decisions)
options.B: Recognize these as issues, involve stakeholders: HR for retention strategy, finance for budget options, compliance for testing approach‚Äîcollaborate on best solutions
options.C: Escalate everything to the sponsor without analysis
options.D: Ignore them until they become critical

quotes.text: Issues are something that's happening on a project that's probably gonna have negative impact. The supplier IS late. The team member IS having conflict. These are not potential risks‚Äîthey're issues. Recognize when a risk becomes an issue, and collaborate with stakeholders to come up with the right solution.
quotes.author: Andrew Ramdayal

quotes.text: Project managers recognize when a risk has materialized into an issue and collaborate with relevant stakeholders to determine the optimal approach to resolve the issue and ensure project success.
quotes.author: PMI

fieldInsights.title: Risk vs. Issue - Know the Difference
fieldInsights.insight: RISK = 'Supplier MIGHT be late' (future, uncertain, prevent/prepare). ISSUE = 'Supplier IS late' (present, real, resolve NOW). On exams, the distinction matters. Risk management is proactive. Issue management is reactive.

personalApplication.title: Personal Reflection

questions.question: What issues (not risks‚Äîactual problems) are happening on your project RIGHT NOW?
questions.placeholder: Example: Team member causing conflict, supplier delay, scope ambiguity...

questions.question: For each issue, who should be involved in finding the best solution?

personalApplication.valueStatement: The best solutions come from collaboration. When you involve stakeholders in solving issues, they buy in more and solutions are better.

memoryPalace.title: Memory Palace: The Mountain Expedition Issue Resolution

story.title: Climbing with Real Problems (Not Just Risks)
story.narrative: Your expedition encounters THREE ISSUES (happening NOW, not potential risks): (1) Lead guide is ill and can't continue (2) Food supplies are 30% less than expected (3) Weather forecast shows storm arriving in 3 days. All REAL PROBLEMS. How do you RESOLVE them?

scenes.description: Guide is sick NOW (issue, not 'might get sick'). Food shortage is happening NOW (issue, not 'might be delayed'). Storm is coming NOW (issue). These require immediate action, not preparation.

Guide illness: Affects team safety + schedule (need new lead). Food shortage: Affects nutrition + schedule (need rationing or resupply). Storm: Affects safety + timeline (shelter needed). All are serious.

Guide illness: Talk to guide, medical officer, backup guide. Food shortage: Talk to supply officer, team members (can we ration?). Storm: Talk to meteorologist, camp manager (where can we shelter?). Get INPUT, don't decide alone.

Guide illness: (A) Continue with backup guide? (B) Stop and wait for recovery? Food: (A) Ration? (B) Send for resupply? Storm: (A) Shelter in place? (B) Adjust route? Discuss options WITH stakeholders.
Decide: Use backup guide. Ration food 20%. Shelter at Camp 2 for 2 days during storm. Communicate clearly: 'Here's what we're doing and why.' Everyone knows their role.
Follow up: Is backup guide working well? Is rationing sustainable? Did team survive storm? Are we back on track? Confirm issues are RESOLVED, not just addressed.

story.moral: RESOLVE: Recognize issues happening NOW, Evaluate their impact, Source stakeholder input (not your decision alone), Optimize options together, Launch implementation, Validate resolution. Real problems need collaborative solutions.
